http://www.un.org/en/ga/president/bios/bio34.shtml (accessed 20 August 2014).
Excerpt from speech given by Salim at the UN on the eve of the UN Resolution on the Admission of China, 25 October 1971.
Diallo Telli, a national of Guinea, replaced Wodajo as secretary-general from 1964 to 1972.
Telli handed over the leadership of the OAU to Nzo Ekangaki, a Cameroonian, who led the organisation from 1972 to 1974.
Another Cameroonian, William Eteki, replaced Ekangaki and held the position of secretary-general from 1974 to 1978.
Subsequently, Edem Kodjo from Togo took over the leadership from 1978 to 1983.
Kodjo was succeeded by the then acting secretary-general, Peter Onu, a Nigerian, who served as the interim secretary-general from 1983 to 1985.
Ide Oumarou from Niger replaced Onu and led the OAU from 1985 to 1989.
UN, Biography of Salim Ahmed Salim, April 2002, www.un.org/News/dh/hlpanel/salim-salim-bio.htm, accessed 25 August 2014.

Plenary Meeting Regarding the Expulsion of the South African Regime from the UNGA, 2 November 1974, New York.
Interview with Salim Ahmed Salim, 7 August 2014, Dar es Salaam.
Diallo Telli, a national of Guinea, replaced Wodajo as secretary-general from 1964 to 1972.
Telli handed over the leadership of the OAU to Nzo Ekangaki, a Cameroonian, who led the organisation from 1972 to 1974.
Subsequently, Edem Kodjo from Togo took over the leadership from 1978 to 1983.
Kodjo was succeeded by the then acting secretary-general, Peter Onu, a Nigerian, who served as the interim secretary-general from 1983 to 1985.
Ide Oumarou from Niger replaced Onu and led the OAU from 1985 to 1989.
Tanzania’s leaders had pleaded with Nigeria to support Onu as an official candidate for the post of secretary-general since he was the only alternative candidate to Oumarou.
